Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wintertexan How is it possible to have negative margins if there was tumor outside your prostate? I think, with no actual knowledge, YES. The cancer could have metastasized via a lymphatic, blood vessel etc and got out that way. It however would be a very rare event. If it was not possible to have any get outside and all cancer was gone, why the heck do they do so much PSA testing? Did the folks at U of I give you an alternative to follow since the vaccine trial was not a match?
Posts.Title: My First Post after reading for 18 months

Posts.Content: I had no surgery, went right into the RT. your psa seems a bit high and the above is a good follow up. for trials to work, they need compliant patients. hormones therapy helps, esp when combined with radiation. that being said, I stopped mine a bit early against my drs wishes, why, any pro from the extended time on hormones was outweighed for me by the side affects. but that is just me, I hated the hormone treatment and stopped early, against drs orders. after I stopped the drs did tell me, we wished you would have stayed on them longer but stopping early is pretty common because some hate them. even if I knew for a fact extended hormone treatment would gurantee 2 more years, I would pass.
Posts.Title: PSA 0.60 3 mon. post RP what did you do for treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dupres In Aug, 2010, I was diagnosed with PCa (PSA-29, Gleason 4+3). In Dec, 2010 I began a 6 month program of Androgen Deprivation Therapy and had IMRT beginning in Feb. 2011. Since that time, my PSA has been raising and, to me, seems high. My results are as follows (note- the 5/31/11 test was while I was still on ADT, which ended in mid June): PSA <0.1 05/31/2011 PSA 0.9 08/30/2011 PSA 1.2 11/29/2011 PSA 1.2 02/27/2012 PSA 1.4 05/22/2012 My urologist says “Your PSA remains stable.” SAY WHAT?!!! I haven’t been able to find out much about post radiation PSA levels, but what I have found would indicate that my case is unusual (to say the least). My PSA seems high and seems to be on an upward trend. When a PSA reaches 2.0 post radiation, it usually is taken to mean the treatment failed. I am on this forum looking for information (how common ARE my results so far), advice, opinions, references to published research, etc. Thanks. What happened, did PSA continue to rise, did you do ADT? I am having the same issue but I have 2 differences, I am at 0.49 right now, 6 months after hormone withdrawal. My dr wants me back on ADT, I am opposed.
Posts.Title: rising PSA post radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Hormone therapy is used in one of two ways..First as an adjunct to some other form of primary treatment be it surgery or radiation. Studies have shown it can increase the effectiveness of SRT, salvage radiation treatment, and it can also be used to augment any radiation treatment. Radiation Oncologists love it because it makes them look good both in the short term and hopefully in the long term.. In the past, HT was used as a primary treatment for late-stage PC discovered before the age of the PSA test. Physical castration was the method employed. This never CURED anyone of Prostate Cancer, but it gave them several years of survival improvement. Today, it still offers no cure, it's a palliative treatment, and drugs are used instead of castration. Since it's effective and relatively inexpensive, it's still used before the newer, far more expensive therapies that are now available..When the HT stops working and the patients PSA continues to rise, it's referred to as becoming "hormone refractory".. The downside of HT are the side-effects...They begin with hot flashes which can be severe, many men feel fatigued and listless, some suffer emotional upsets, all sex drive and ability quickly evaporates, breast development begins, body hair disappears, ones personality becomes a lot more "mellow"... Not everyone suffers all these things at the same time, but as the duration of treatment grows longer, the side-effects become more prominent..The unspoken truth is that few men have to endure HT for prolonged periods of time....Another unspoken truth, the longer you are on HT, the longer it takes to recover from it and after 3 years or so, the effect of the drugs becomes permanent in most men... Men without health insurance might wish to consider physical castration as the long-term cost of the drugs used can be quite high. Castration is the least expensive form of HT and it's thought to be the most effective as it lowers testosterone levels to almost nothing... Good review of the negative side affects. I experienced them all in the 4 months I was on hormones. The sexual side affects were not that hard to deal with, but the hot flashes, fatigue, etc were bad. The depression hit me big time at like 4 months on treatment and it appeared the hormones had done its job. I could have gotten medication to counteract the depression but I just stopped the hormones 2 months early. In regards to your suggestion to possibly get castration I disagree. The thing about hormones is that you can stop the treatment when side affects get so bad that no matter the benefit they afford, the cons outweigh it. As far as I know, you can't get un-castarated. If due to financial reasons, I would not continue on hormones long-term, I would be ok with that as they are palliative (your words) and have huge side-affects for me and many. Even if they offered more than just palliative benefits, I personally would be very concerned taking them again. HAVING SAID THAT, HORMONES ARE USED BY MANY AND THEY ARE OK WITH THE SIDE AFFECTS. I WAS NOT.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy EXBT, HDBT I'm not familiar with those acronyms. Could you please tell me what those 2 modalities are? EXBT AND HDBT. Both are radiation. EXBT. External Beam Therapy. They zap you from the outside of your body. HDBT High Dose Brachiotherapy, you get radioactive material right in your prostate. As it is high dose, it is a temporary procedure. LDBT, low dose brachiotherapy refers to radioactive material being left in as it is not that radioactive. Their is no decent data comparing high -dose vs. low dose but I choose high-dose as my radiologists said if it was him that is what he would get, I said why. He said since it is very temporary, they make sure they position it right where they want it. They may not do that as good with low dose and the radioactive implants may move a bit over time so they are not as concerned with placement. I think the Dr doing it is more imp than the procedure I feel, but it is a crap shoot on picking HDBT vs LDBT.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SeaCock Thanks newporter... Here is my uneducated thoughts; I feel that if testosterone causes PC to get worse...wouldn't PC be a young mans disease. The older we get the lower our test gets, the more likely you are to get PC. So I think a case could be made that lower...or dropping test causes PC to kick off and start being an issue. It just seems like if it is truce test causes cancer to grow and be more active...young men should be more prone to cancer than older men... Testosterone may be important, how important is open to debate. In regards to younger men having higher T and little PCa (a theory talked about by others with expertise in this field) I think that is a red herring. Why? Young folks that smoke may have lower rates of certain cancer types than older non-smokers do. Does that mean smoking is unrelated to cancer? NO. It means smoking and other factors, like age, are involved. I am NOT saying testosterone has a major role in prostate cancer, I am saying that age of onset is not a way to determine the importance of testosterone. If one wants to determine if T plays a role, you cannot mess up the data by using different age groups in the analysis. The best research is done by looking at one variable at a time and trying to hold everything else the same in both groups.
Posts.Signature: PSA 5/12 14.1 10/12 19.66 11/12 20.23 12/12 1.93 1/13 0.17 2/13 0.09 3/13 0.02 6/13 0.35 9/13 0.49 10/13 0.40 1/14 0.40 DRE Normal. CAT, MRI, and bone scan all normal. Biopsy 10/12. 3 of 12 positive, 3 + 4. All pos were on right side. 10% of tissue affected. Treatment Casodex/Lupron for 4 months, started Nov 12. Ex Beam Rad Ther Started Jan 1. High Dose Brachiotherapy started 3/12. Casodex/Lupron was to be for 6 months and I stopped early against Drs. orders.

Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before My Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Oh, this might put my personal views in perspective. I have had EXBT, HDBT and hormones. For EXBT I had to go everyday for 5 weeks and get zapped while have a full bladder. For HDBT, I was strapped in a hospital bed for 2 days, had no food at all for those 2 days and had 18 needles shoved into my prostate in the skin between my rectum and scrotum. I had Lupron and bicaltumide for 4 months. If I was called up and told, you need 15 more weeks of EXBT and 6 more 2 day sessions of HDBT I would say sure. I do not think I would be nearly so ready to go back on hormones. Even I was told they are my only hope for living I might say, ok, how long do I live with them and without them.
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before My Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SeaCock My favorite subject...revisited from another angle... Has any one received Testosterone to help you recover your erections? I forgot to ask on my last URO. visit...I had so many questions and took up so much time I could tell he needed to move on to the next patient. I think he has a surgery nearly every day. When I was in the hospital most of the guys on my floor where his patients. All with the same procedure...most others were different Doctors...one Dr. had two guys... So any way; Any one receive testosterone? Did it help? What was their goal testosterone level? Last time I had mine checked it was 330...bottom edge of except able. Mine, based on multiple tests over the last 3 years averages about 290. 3 years ago I noted on this board a few were using T supplements and their Dr. did it based on very scant data. I was not interested. Due to a recent scare (false one b y the way) I revisited the data on PCa and now it seems that a number of Drs. have a different view and their is more data to base the decision on. I asked my oncologist last month about T supplementation and she said NO WAY will she prescribe it, which I figured. However, I told her I might do it anyway. I found a Dr. that prescribes it and I will likely start T therapy next month. I am not that concerned about T supplementation causing a recurrence of prostate cancer (the area is debated by experts) and no one lives forever anyway. My major concern is that once you start on T replacement your body stops making endogenous T and it may be a life long therapy. I will get my T levels tested every 3 months and my oncoligist will likely notice a spike and yell at me. She knows her stuff but also knows that I am a cocky bastard that thinks he knows everything, lol. But I already have a good answer for her, well I know you think this is a bad move BUT if my prostate cancer does return I will stop T replacement and probably go to very low T without having to repeat that chemical castration crap. I have taken leupron and bicalitumide in the past and the data said it was the right thing to do. I took it for 4 months. If my cancer returns and even if I am convinced that returning to that treatment would extend my life, I may not take it. So that should be taken into account when you look at my decision. Death vs chemical castaration, that would be a tuf call if I ever had to make it.

It just seems like if it is truce test causes cancer to grow and be more active...young men should be more prone to cancer than older men... Testosterone may be important, how important is open to debate. In regards to younger men having higher T and little PCa (a theory talked about by others with expertise in this field) I think that is a red herring. Why? Young folks that smoke may have lower rates of certain cancer types than older non-smokers do. Does that mean smoking is unrelated to cancer? NO. It means smoking and other factors, like age, are involved. I am NOT saying testosterone has a major role in prostate cancer, I am saying that age of onset is not a way to determine the importance of testosterone. If one wants to determine if T plays a role, you cannot mess up the data by using different age groups in the analysis. The best research is done by looking at one variable at a time and trying to hold everything else the same in both groups.

Posts.Title: Is it true that black men are more likely to get prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: I had radiation treatment for my PCa about 3 years ago and things went great, my PSA dropped. About 2 months, with routine follow up testing, it shot up. My oncologist said I am setting up a bone scan, MRI and CT here (in Iowa) and you should go to Mayo for a choline scan (choline scan is much more sensirive and good for recurrent PCa). Since I have HMO and Mayo is not in my region, insurance issues. So I was in a quandry. I checked around and the hospital in Decataur Illnois offered the choline scan. They do a regulasr MRI, CT and then do a choline one. I said my insurance will not pay anything and they said most will be 1500. Great deal. The nurse at that location gives EXCELLENT CUSTOMER SERVICE. She gave me local hotels to stay at (it is a 5 hour drive) and the tests start aT 9 AM AND END AT 1 PM. They tell you if they found anything and give you a CD with images on to take back to your local Dr (customer service). Cheap and quick and nice. It is part of a clinical trial so you can get details on it by searching the NIH clinical trial thing. You must have recurrent PCa as determined by a rise in PSA, details on the trial details. https://www.centerwatch.com/clinical...catur&State=IL My elevated PSA was a lab mistake sop I did not need this service as 2 subsequent PSA tests have shown it was a false positive. But the price and service seemed great so I am passing this on. Another thing, FUSION biopsy. That is when the person doing the biopsy uses the sensitive scan along with an real time ultrasound scan to target the most likely area of cancer. Regulsr biopsys are randomof the prostate and may miss the cancerous portion. I think it very important to do a fusion biopsy for recurrent PCa as it might be hard to find where to sample as the initial treatment makes youir prostate real small or non-existent. I talked to my local doc, should I bring back the CD and have the biopsy person use that to do a fusion biopsy (most places do not do the choline scan). She said NO. A fusion biopsy would be improved she felt if the person doing the fusion biopsy does them often, and the local hospital does not do them often. I hope this imnformation is not needed as no one should have recurrent PCa, but if you do, I have done some of the leg work for your journey. A positive note, just a few years ago the treatment for recurrent PCa was very limited but it has really exploded recently. So some of the newer therapies and expeerimntal therapies offer us great hope.

Posts.Content: I want to thank you very much brave. The Chicago study, which is in my neck of the woods, showed the biggest reduction in prostate cancer recurrence following radiation of high risk patients with no evidence of metasize thst were over 50 years. Those on the drugs have about a 18 percent chance of cancer returning and those not taking them 42 percent at 4 years. As I was in the high risk category I figured a 50 % chance of recurrence at 5 years. But that was older rad doses so with the newer dose I dropped it to 35%. Now with the fact that I am on warfarin I can go from 18 to 10, I am kicking ass. lol. They think the anti-cosgulant may make the cancer cells more sus to radiation as it may alter the biochemistry of the cells. AWESOME. The authors did state that warfarin and radiation increases the chance of rectal bleeding but bloody poop is better thzn cancer coming back. lol.

Posts.Content: OK, I think this may be an article we all should read. http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/30/35/4294.full The authors work at John Hopkins and discuss upgrading after surgery etc. They state at the start. "Overtreatment of low-grade prostate cancer (Gleason score  6) is a recognized problem today, with systematic prostate gland sampling triggered by prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurements.1 The extent to which overtreatment is caused by fear of death resulting from cancer, fear of litigation from undertreatment, and misaligned incentives that reimburse more for treating rather than monitoring when appropriate is not known. Nevertheless, fear of death resulting from cancer likely plays some role, and removing the label “cancer” could reduce unnecessary treatment of low-grade disease.2,3 On the other hand, undertreatment of prostate cancer and a missed opportunity for cure in those who could benefit is a real risk of relabeling a cancer as noncancer. We have decided on an alternative modification of the Gleason scoring system and herein present the arguments for and against removing the label of cancer from Gleason 6 tumors. We believe that our alternative approach may help: one, ensure that patients receive the proper counseling/treatment; two, reduce the risk of overtreatment and its associated harms; and three, improve shared decision making. ."

Even if still high at next Dr visit you still have to wait for biopsy results then wait on what to due etc. But it is your money but it might not ht change a thing. This is my personal view.

Posts.Content: "You should also be aware, however, (perhaps you aready know this) that the biopsy report is only an educated guess. About 28% of surgically removed prostates are revealed by post-op pathology to also have harbored tumors with HIGHER Gleason scores." This above raises an issue to me. We have seen the research data on risk category, treatment options survivability. I think that risk category was, and should have been collected using the same method. You can then assign a person into a group using the biopsy results and keep them in that group for sur, rad or AS. Even if the gleason score changed after sur (say it went to 7) it should be a 6 for a valid study. Regardless of if I am believed, I think you need to ask your dr. If the dr. is unable to know how the data was collected, or does not care, find a new dr. in the research game they often say, garbage in, garbage out. and reclassifying only thosr that get sur is garbage. use biopsy results for all.

Posts.Content: OK, I think this may be an article we all should read. http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/30/35/4294.full The authors work at John Hopkins and discuss upgrading after surgery etc. They state at the start. "Overtreatment of low-grade prostate cancer (Gleason score  6) is a recognized problem today, with systematic prostate gland sampling triggered by prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurements.1 The extent to which overtreatment is caused by fear of death resulting from cancer, fear of litigation from undertreatment, and misaligned incentives that reimburse more for treating rather than monitoring when appropriate is not known. Nevertheless, fear of death resulting from cancer likely plays some role, and removing the label “cancer” could reduce unnecessary treatment of low-grade disease.2,3 On the other hand, undertreatment of prostate cancer and a missed opportunity for cure in those who could benefit is a real risk of relabeling a cancer as noncancer. We have decided on an alternative modification of the Gleason scoring system and herein present the arguments for and against removing the label of cancer from Gleason 6 tumors. We believe that our alternative approach may help: one, ensure that patients receive the proper counseling/treatment; two, reduce the risk of overtreatment and its associated harms; and three, improve shared decision making. ."

Posts.Content: I had it in first part of 2013. During treatment, severe urination problems. Example, I went from the radiation treatment center to see one of my doctors who was 45 minutes away. He said any urination issues, I said I only stopped 4 times on the drive (called a pee cup in the car and never passing a bathroom, lol). Now, that is no longer an issue. No meds, only get up once a night to pee. I was getting up 4 times a night during treatment. ED, a significant issue, finally broke down and Viagra is on the way. Should arrive today as I have a date 2night with a new woman. Maybe if it does not arrive I can act like, I want to wait so I get to know you better. That sounds better than saying, the friggin post office has not got my Viagra to me yet.

Posts.Content: thanks, the biggest drawback i see is that this was a retrospective study, not a randomized one. 1) a director of womans studies, any background in test therapy or prostate. 2) i agree correlation does not always mean causation but it might. She/He is a gynecologist? they did look at numerous other conditions that the patients suffered from (includid lipid levels) and the Tes Ther was known as it was a prescription, so it was not willy nilly administration. The article is also similar to 3 other published studies. There is one study where tes levels had the opposite affect but those were naturally occuring test levels not from therapy. we can always find a few doctors that disagree with the majority, and they might be right. but i will wait on tes ther till we get data from the nih clinical trials, which are randomized. from the article i found the most interesting conclusion was this, studies funded by the pharm industry did not have much of a neg affect but in studies funded by different ways, the tes ther was big. seems like the funding source affects the results and that is interesting as heck.

HOWEVER, that data you see is based on old rad doses as the machines used when studies were started kina hit the other organs and the machines they use know are more targeted. So they have upped the rads doses. So take what you read with a grain of salt as we got higher doses and likely have better odds. what was your dre? any image evidence of outside of prostate? did you get imrt alone or brachiotherapy on top of imrt?

Posts.Title: Age 73, PSA 10, Gleason 8

Posts.Content: Since you are twins, I will give my 2 cents worth. I have read countless articles and am shocked by the lack of definitive research. But then in retrospect, I realized that the differing opinions of the experts are due to the fact that their is a lot of unknown due to the slow nature of PCa so they guess a bit. In other words, who really knows. If it was me, I would stay with AS till my PSA reached 10 or if the biopsy went up to 7. But Bud thinks he will live 30 years so maybe that means I am being to much AS liking. If Bud goes for the treatment, who knows. I chose radiation (both beam and brachiotherapy) for a strange reason, it did not interfere with my bike riding. That was my decision maker. The urologist, guy doing the surgery kinna agreed as my PSA was high (19) suggesting that I had some mets outside of my prostate so zapping would be better. The beam zaps were expanded to my lymph nodes to give any extra-prostatic cancer a zap. The advantage to surgery is you can easily do follow up with radiation but not the other way around. I also choose the radiation as that was part of the trial at my local hospital and I like trials, more data is always good. I was FURIOUS when I got kicked out of trial however. I was eligible and the 2 places doing the 2 types of radiation were enrolled in doing the trial. However, the expert for the ex beam was at a hospital 30 miles from the dude who did the brachiotherapy. I was thinking, since they both are in the trial I will be fine, I was not allowed to go to 2 places, had to go to only 1 if I was to stay in the trial. I choose doing the 2 places, as that was best for me. And when they did the brachiotherapy, the ex beam guy and his team came down and learned that procedure and are now instituting that. So it was a very crowded surgery room. I also looked at radiation success, surgery seemed to have a bit better results but that data is based on lower and older dosages. They are using higher doses now so likely it is equal to surgery, but time will tell. I also considered (guessed) high does radiation vs surgery followed by radiation. Hard to compare those 2 as it is not known when using high dose. So, I have answered by saying, no definite answer, so who knows. I think this may give you insight into how I think. My one dr thought I relapsed based on my post radiation PSA amounts, I knew she was wrong. I had a follow up with another Dr and he said, you have no evidence of relapse, my daughter was with me. She saw me smile and then said, you seem to be more happy with being right than with knowing your cancer has not returned, I said of course I am. Cancer is not that biggie to me, being smarter than my drs is what gets me excited. And I hate to say this, but the penalty for me being wrong makes this even more exciting, that is strange but I do enjoy that part.

Posts.Title: DEBATE: Talk Bud (G6) out of Surgery - Warning: Content may not be for the meek

Posts.Content: Since you are twins, I will give my 2 cents worth. I have read countless articles and am shocked by the lack of definitive research. But then in retrospect, I realized that the differing opinions of the experts are due to the fact that their is a lot of unknown due to the slow nature of PCa so they guess a bit. In other words, who really knows. If it was me, I would stay with AS till my PSA reached 10 or if the biopsy went up to 7. But Bud thinks he will live 30 years so maybe that means I am being to much AS liking. If Bud goes for the treatment, who knows. I chose radiation (both beam and brachiotherapy) for a strange reason, it did not interfere with my bike riding. That was my decision maker. The urologist, guy doing the surgery kinna agreed as my PSA was high (19) suggesting that I had some mets outside of my prostate so zapping would be better. The beam zaps were expanded to my lymph nodes to give any extra-prostatic cancer a zap. The advantage to surgery is you can easily do follow up with radiation but not the other way around. I also choose the radiation as that was part of the trial at my local hospital and I like trials, more data is always good. I was FURIOUS when I got kicked out of trial however. I was eligible and the 2 places doing the 2 types of radiation were enrolled in doing the trial. However, the expert for the ex beam was at a hospital 30 miles from the dude who did the brachiotherapy. I was thinking, since they both are in the trial I will be fine, I was not allowed to go to 2 places, had to go to only 1 if I was to stay in the trial. I choose doing the 2 places, as that was best for me. And when they did the brachiotherapy, the ex beam guy and his team came down and learned that procedure and are now instituting that. So it was a very crowded surgery room. I also looked at radiation success, surgery seemed to have a bit better results but that data is based on lower and older dosages. They are using higher doses now so likely it is equal to surgery, but time will tell. I also considered (guessed) high does radiation vs surgery followed by radiation. Hard to compare those 2 as it is not known when using high dose. So, I have answered by saying, no definite answer, so who knows. I think this may give you insight into how I think. My one dr thought I relapsed based on my post radiation PSA amounts, I knew she was wrong. I had a follow up with another Dr and he said, you have no evidence of relapse, my daughter was with me. She saw me smile and then said, you seem to be more happy with being right than with knowing your cancer has not returned, I said of course I am. Cancer is not that biggie to me, being smarter than my drs is what gets me excited. And I hate to say this, but the penalty for me being wrong makes this even more exciting, that is strange but I do enjoy that part.

Posts.Content: Your PSA seems great, the upward trend is not to worry about as it is still in the undetectable range. undetrectable is all you should care about. in regard to the relatively lower T level affecting PSA, I have not seen any data saying they are linked, but no info saying they are not linked. in other words you asked a good question but I do not think anyone has the answer. and I looked relatively hard on this specific question. Originally Posted by traveller Hi Bigbrad, My PSA post op was 0.02 then 0.03. I started adjuvant HT and then adjuvant RT. After starting Lupron, my PSA dropped to 0.003 and stayed there throughout the hormone and radiation therapies. I had my last Lupron shot (3 months) in June 2012, my PSA continued to be at 0.003 until July 2013 when it slightly increased to 0.007. T level was 6 during hormone therapy and then rose to 486 in April 2013. Recently in September this year, PSA was 0.01, still undetectable, but there may be an upward trend. T level dropped to 350. I think T level will stabilize at a lower level, I feel there is decrease in my libido, and am curious if the relatively lower T level has any effect on PSA level and velocity

Posts.Content: This is a simple overview on patent issues. "Are Products of Nature Included in the List of What Cannot Be Patented? While simply identifying a product of nature like a gene or a hormone will not be enough to warrant a patent, if you are able to purify the product, you may be able to get a patent. Although genes, hormones, and other chemicals are products of nature, they do not exist naturally in isolated form. Thus, if you are able to isolate, purify, or somehow alter a product of nature, you may be able to patent it. "

Posts.Title: post radiation PSA results at 30 months after treatment completed

Posts.Content: I have been in your situation partially. I had a 3 + 4 and PSA of 20. I had both the ex beam and brachytherapy and hormones for 4 months. My PSA dropped and is still down, according to my definition and one of my drs. If my PSA shoots up, I will likely get more treatment. The thought of going back on hormones is not a fun thought and I may say, no thanks. If I did, I would do the intermittent treatment. In regards to surgery, it is a pain to do but some drs say it works. I think it works when compared to other treatment options, which are not very good (more hormones). So I have thought about this issue a lot. I have decided, if needed, to look for clinical trials available. I do not qualify for them as most require a PSA of 2 or higher. The current ones to choose, ask your Drs. If it was me, I would enroll at the trial going on at U of Iowa. Why, 1) close by. And 2, they are conducting vaccine trials and are using a vaccine approach I have used in animals, so I think that is cool. Is that the best means of treating, I actually doubt it but we always need more data. My views (which are mine alone) is that PCa may not be bad, hormones are, surgery after rads is hard, and clinical trials may be the best route.
Posts.Title: Need opinions on next step

Posts.Content: I am a big vaccine believer because that is my area/job. The vaccines I have worked with are NOT for human cancer, so I am not knowledgeable on them (what type of vaccine is best (ie the backbone/ manufacturing process; what antigen should in the vaccine, how many doses, how much vaccine etc). Those things I have no clue on. I just like the science. Vaccines should have no or little side affects, so worth a look. In regards to if it works, take what you hear in the regular news with a very big grain of salt and those by the experts a slightly smaller grain. The great thing about PCa is it is often very slow growing, bad thing, it takes years before finding out that a new treatment is worthless. I like HIFU but I think the newest data suggests it has little impact, some experts will disagree but some will agree with me.
Posts.Title: Need opinions on next step

Posts.Content: http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials...hormonertx0209 http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/hor...3/METHOD=print Results of Treating Prostate Cancer with Radiation Therapy and Hormone Therapy Optimizing Hormone Therapy in Localized Prostate Cancer: Focus on External Beam Radiotherapy SANDLER, HOWARD M. Journal of Urology. Innovations and Challenges in Prostate Cancer: Prevention, Detection and Treatment: Fourth International Conference. 172(5, Part 2 of 2) Supplement:S38-S41, November 2004. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the use of hormone therapy when combined with radiotherapy prior to a radical prostatectomy. Physicians analyzed ongoing clinical trials in an effort to identify prostate cancer patients who will benefit most from this combination. In patients with low Gleason scores, short-term androgen ablation improved cause specific survival rates. For high-grade prostate cancer, long-term androgen ablation is required. Patients at intermediate risk are candidates for short-term androgen ablation, however there is a lack of trials that assess overall treatment benefit. Doctors advise patients with low risk prostate cancer to not receive androgen ablation unless additional data support a substantial clinical benefit. Patients with a high-risk for pelvic lymph node involvement may receive whole pelvic radiotherapy in order to maximize biochemical interaction. Hormonal Therapy and Radiotherapy for Localized Prostate Cancer: Who, Where, and How Long? ROACH, MACK III Journal of Urology. 170(6, Part 2 of 2):S35-S41, December 2003. In this study 1, 323 patients with a risk of lymph node involvement greater than 15 percent were analyzed to determine the success rate of hormone therapy used with external beam radiation. Long-term hormone therapy was tested against short-term. Doctors compared whole pelvis radiotherapy, radiotherapy of the prostate alone, neoadjuvant hormone therapy and concurrent hormone therapy with radiotherapy, and radiotherapy with adjuvant hormone therapy. They strived to find out which one out of the four would most improve progression-free survival. After five years, all four treatments were contrasted and whole pelvis radiotherapy as well as neoadjuvant and concurrent hormone therapy with radiotherapy were found to be the best options in the improvement of progression-free survival. Neoadjuvant Hormone Therapy Before Salvage Radiotherapy for an Increasing Post-radical Prostatectomy Serum Prostate Specific Antigen Level TIGUERT, RABI; RIGAUD, JEROME; LACOMBE, LOUIS; LAVERDIERE, JACQUES; FRADET, YVES Journal of Urology. 170(2, Part 1):447-450, August 2003. Within this study doctors retrospectively evaluated 81 patients who were treated with neoadjuvant androgen deprivation therapy before salvage external beam radiation treatment due to an increased PSA level following radical retropubic prostatectomy. Patients were analyzed based on the outcome of preoperative, pathological, postoperative characteristics, pre-salvage treatment, and radiation therapy. Prior to the salvage radiotherapy patients received a 3-month injection of a luteinizing hormone releasing hormone analogue. Doctors followed up with their patients approximately 38 months after external beam radiation and 91 months after radical prostatectomy. At three years 75% of patients were free of biochemical failure and 50% were at 5 years. Two patients (2 percent) died of prostate cancer. Those who benefited most from this treatment were patients with a pre-radiation PSA level less than 1 and a Gleason score less than 7.

Posts.Title: Hi From Melbourne!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by traveller Hi, I am a G8 and have been through surgery, ART and AHT. After stopping the hormone therapy my T level was restored. My question is does it matter to have high or low T levels on PSA? In other words, if there is residual cancer cells and PSA increases due to increase in testosterone, will PSA increase higher and faster if T level is higher (i.e. T level being 500ng/ml vs 200ng/ml). First of all, I could be very wrong on this. Testosterone has been thought to add fuel to the fire so that is why exogenous T is normally not recommended for those with PCa. Your situation, like mine, is different than the preceding. You are measuring endogenous T which has rebounded due to the affects of the hormones going away. In my case, both went up and I think that happens to everyone who did NOT get surgery and had AHT. What I mean is my PSA went from non-detrectable levels from ADT and when off them, to went to 0.4, which is normal post-radiation. After surgery, PSA should stay very low. They measure the T to see if the ADT worked and then to see if the side affects wore off. I have looked at a paper which did a ratio of T to PSA before any treatment (Japaneses paper I think) and I think they could predict future PCa a bit if the T.PSA ratio was skewed a bit. Question, after stopping ADT, your T went up, which is expected. Did your PSA go up. The only way to not have T go up I feel is stay on ADT or get castarated. T has some great affects, and I like them. I do NOT think you should worry at all about endsoigernous T levels that are acting like expected.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago I'd get the PSA test done about March 3rd or 4th... allowing even more time for any inflammation to have calmed down since December and your round of antibiotics. Then I'd not get the PSA results until you return from your nice RV trip. If the results are still high, you can then do a quick biopsy. There is little to be lost in delaying a few weeks and depending on the results of either the psa or the biopsy, you could really ruin your trip. Right now, I'd assume the best and not get any results before you return. Imagine how your RV trip will be if you get a high psa or especially a positive core in a biopsy. After all, regardless of the results of those tests, you won't be taking any immediate action. Why possible ruin a good trip. Get the PSA test just before you leave... even the day before... or the day you return. Don't feel the need to call in quick and get the PSA result before you leave. Don't have it emailed to you or call to get it. Yes, sometimes a "head in the sand" approach is the best, especially with a potential very slow growing prostate cancer. That is funny, I love knowing all things ASAP but you differ Otago. It varies from individual to individual. The good thing is you were told by many here it is not that bad and immediate action is not needed. The rest is schedule and personal view. I squeezed my biopsy in so I could have the results in Macchu Piccho. I can't imagine not knowing, lol.

Posts.Content: as detailed below, I was diagnosed with PCa about 1 year ago and completed my tri-modal treatment (EXBT, HDBT and 4 months hormone therapy). I have no clinical signs or evidence of metasis. My PSA at end of treatment (bith hormone and radition stopped at same time) was 0.02, rose to 0.35 3 months after treatment and 0.49 6 months after treatment. the day my oncologist and I got the 6 months results, she said I was to back on hormone treatment for life (or until I developed castration resistant cancer). Due to an insurance problem, it did not happen immediately and I decided 1) to get a second opionon 2) decided the oncologist is using the old ASTRO criteria which has lots of false positives and 3) I will wait till it gets to 2. my question, do you think that my oncologist is over reacting? the psa rise is only "abnormal" following completion of my tri-modal treatment. 7/12 PSA 13.5 All DRE were negative. 11/12 PSA 19.0 Gleason of 7 (3 + 4), 3 of 12 biopsies positive, all positives in left lobe. MRI, CAT SCAN, BONE SCAN conducted in early 2013 were neg for mets. ADT (LUPRON AND BICALUMATIDE) STARTED 12/12 AND ENDED 4 MONTH LATER. EXBT (35 ZAPS I THINK) STARTED 12/12, PELVIC LYMPH NODES GOT SOME RADS. HDBT 3/13. I DO NOT KNOW THE TOTAL gREY DOSAGE GIVEN BUT IT WAS THE MAX I THINK. Posts.Title: Newbie, prostate cancer diagnosis after a health fair blood test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter A couple of comments: 1. Fairwind made an excellent point, in a standard radiation treatment, PSA does not go to undetectable immediately so your .02 PSA is most likely caused by the hormone. However, if hormone is what caused the PSA to be undetectable, then from what I read and from many of the posts here, PSA should stay low for some time and not rising immediately after it stops. Maybe you stopped too soon? 2. Most of the literatures I read about adjuvant hormone in radiation treatment started with hormone prior to radiation and usually continued for 6, 12 to 18 months after radiation. To stop right after radiation seemed unusual? 3. If you did not have adjuvant hormone therapy, PSA usually drops slowly and won't reach nadir for sometime, perhaps 12 to 24 months. So, my recommendation is to seek another opinion or perhaps get back to hormone. Best wishes. In regards to rising, I think my PSA rose quickly as my testosterone did as well. The test rise shows hormone action wore off and that is why my PSA rose. In rewards to how long on hormones is up for debate. The guidelines for treating high risk prostate cancer in Sept 2012 is EXBT, HDBT and maybe 4-6 months of hormone. The docs wanted 6, I said 4 is enough. And the experts say MAYBE. The guidelines were then revised in Jan 2013 to EXBT, HDBT, and MAYBE 2-3 years hormone therapy. Again, MAYBE. There are only 2 publications I could find on hormone effectiveness in tri-modal treatment. They were very small studies (one in Cal and one in Brazil) and the studies had some issues but they did NOT find a benefit to using hormones. I was like, the experts say MAYBE and change the time length to use them and there is some weak data saying they don't help, I stopped. Little pro, lots of con. A big study is being set up in Japan and it appears it will be done properly where they compare the trimodal treatment with short termn hormone usage to tri-modal treatment with long-term hormone care.
Posts.Title: rising psa post tri-modal treatment.

Posts.Content: I have read those studies and agree. But those were based on EXBT alone with hormones. That is a bi-modal treatment. So in that case clearly the longer you were on hormones the better. The only issue with those studies is that they were done using lower radiation than what is usually done now so they may not be perfect. A good review of tri-modal treatment is here. http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2407/12/110. I still cannot believe they got it published as it has not generated data, they just say how they will collect it. Tri-modal SUPPOSEDLY is better than bi-modal cause your prostate gets two methods of radiating. PS I am a dr, not a real dr. a pig doctor so cancer is not a concern, we just eat em lol.
Posts.Title: rising psa post tri-modal treatment.

Posts.Content: the article above is from 2012, so it is recent. These are the important points. "In patients at greater risk for EPE, a BT boost combined with additional EBRT can ensure adequate margin of coverage of surrounding tissues even in the case of minimal spread of disease. As there is mounting evidence that dose escalation leads to a decrease in the rate of treatment failure [27-29], this combined BT and supplemental EBRT is now commonly used to provide a very conformal high-dose-boost to the prostate. Indeed, this synergistic effect of the combination strategy of two types of RT can induce a greater biologically effective dose (BED), the values of which are strongly correlated with treatment outcomes in biochemical control of disease [6,30". AND "Accordingly, we have designed this TRIP study of trimodality treatment consisting of 125I-BT, EBRT, and either short- or long- term HT for high-risk PCa. To our knowledge, there have been no previous reports of prospective studies documenting the efficacy and safety of trimodality therapy for high-risk PCa patients. "

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njs No, it doesn't work that way. The chance of hitting the cancer depends mostly on the percentage of prostate that contains cancer. For example, if the tumor is 10% of the prostate, then a single core has around 10% chance (actually a little more because the core has length vs being a single point) of hitting tumor or about a 90% chance of missing. But a 2nd core has another more-or-less independent 10% chance of hitting the cancer. For cancer involving 10% of the prostate the chances of all 12 cores missing tumor (false negative) would be 0.9 ^12 = 28% or about a 72% chance of finding it. Solid explanation njs. In regards to why not get if you on AS. Biopsy are somewhat uncomfortable (I remember the 12 spring loaded snaps) and they have complications sometime. I would get it if the Doctor felt it needed. In regards to ins, more people getting biopsies mean higher premiums for all. I do have a question, of my 12 biopsies, the positives were only on one side. This was a good thing as it suggested the tumor may have not spread/been aggressive. Of the 6 biopsies on the left, 3 were positive. I asked the urologist, were those positive from adjacent biopsies. He said it does not matter. I call BS on that. If you have 3 of 6 positive samples, and the positive 3 are together is better than if they are spread out. I think they only keep track of left and right when taking biopsies so my question was not answered as the data was not taken. What do you folks think?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njs No, it doesn't work that way. The chance of hitting the cancer depends mostly on the percentage of prostate that contains cancer. For example, if the tumor is 10% of the prostate, then a single core has around 10% chance (actually a little more because the core has length vs being a single point) of hitting tumor or about a 90% chance of missing. But a 2nd core has another more-or-less independent 10% chance of hitting the cancer. For cancer involving 10% of the prostate the chances of all 12 cores missing tumor (false negative) would be 0.9 ^12 = 28% or about a 72% chance of finding it. Solid explanation njs. In regards to why not get if you on AS. Biopsy are somewhat uncomfortable (I remember the 12 spring loaded snaps) and they have complications sometime. I would get it if the Doctor felt it needed. In regards to ins, more people getting biopsies mean higher premiums for all. I do have a question, of my 12 biopsies, the positives were only on one side. This was a good thing as it suggested the tumor may have not spread/been aggressive. Of the 6 biopsies on the left, 3 were positive. I asked the urologist, were those positive from adjacent biopsies. He said it does not matter. I call BS on that. If you have 3 of 6 positive samples, and the positive 3 are together is better than if they are spread out. I think they only keep track of left and right when taking biopsies so my question was not answered as the data was not taken. What do you folks think?

Posts.Title: New to Forum

Posts.Content: "What I'm suggesting is we shouldn't be offering false hope for high PSA results to readers of this blog without scientific evidence. Correct me if I'm wrong or off task here, or at least let this be a thread for discussion." I have seen lots of advice offered here without evidence. Same thing goes for advice by the drs. Lots of things about PCa have very little solid scientific evidence. So most advice should be taken with knowledge that it is based on personal feelings/biases. The only drawback I see is that when one tries to place advice as gospel when there is no scientific backing. The advice may lead to unneccesary surgery or risk from not having surgery. A BIG DEAL. Even PSA testing frequency has a cost associated with it. So I take most of the advice with a big grain of salt. And in regards to bypassing sex for a few days having no harm, you might have a frying pan upside your head from your wife. I think that is harm. lol. The exception being it is fine to bypass sex with a gf, wives like it when you abstain from that activity with your gf.

I know that to some this is a vain reason but that is one thing that has me leaning toward HDR since it and surgery have close to equal cure rates. That seems logical to me as your prostate gets pretty well destroyed.
